Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Digression: units of Measurement • Data sizes: KB, MB, GB, TB (in bytes) • K, M, G, T are multiples of 2 (210, 220, 230, 240) • Except for disk drive manufacturers • Rates: Kbps, Mbps, Gbps, Tbps • K, M, G, T are multiples of 10 (103, 106, 109, 1012) • If KB/s, MB/s, GB/s, TB/s, then use multiples of 2 (210, 220, 230, 240) Read the units carefully 6CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Data size vs data rate • Discrepancy grows with size • 103 vs 210 off by 2.4% • 106 vs 220 off by 4.9% • 109 vs 230 off by 7.4% • 1012 vs 240 off by 10.0% 7CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Bandwidth and Station-wagons 8 “Never underestimate the bandwidth of a station wagon full of tapes hurtling down the highway.” –Andrew Tanenbaum, 1981 Cisco estimates that total internet traffic currently averages 167 terabits per second. FedEx has a fleet of 654 aircraft with a lift capacity of 26.5 million pounds daily. A solid-state laptop drive weighs about 78 grams and can hold up to a terabyte. That means FedEx is capable of transferring 150 exabytes of data per day, or 14 petabits per second—almost a hundred times the current throughput of the internet. GBytes 12CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Network Metrics: Latency • Latency: delay from when something is sent until it is received • “Something” depends on context, but must be consistent • Examples: • Packet latency: from start of sending packet until completely received • Bit/byte latency: from start of sending bit/byte until that bit/byte is completely received 14CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Vehicle Analogy 15CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Pipe Analogy 16CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi It’s the Latency, Stupid • Fact One: Making more bandwidth is easy • Fact Two: Once you have bad latency you're stuck with it • Fact Three: Current consumer devices have appallingly bad latency • Fact Four: Making limited bandwidth go further is easy • This is not to say bandwidth is unimportant: Bandwidth Still Matters 17 http://www.stuartcheshire.org/rants/latency.html http://www.stuartcheshire.org/rants/latency.html CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Network Metrics: RTT • Round Trip Time (RTT): latency for sending something and receiving something back • Latency for message + latency for response + processing time • The RTT for a bit is not the same as the RTT for a request and a response • Easier to compute than one-way latency (single clock) • Reported by ping, traceroute, etc. 18CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Ping (Measure RTT) 19 Observe that not all ping times are the same CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Network Metrics: Jitter • Jitter: variation in latency and/or RTT 20CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi What Causes Jitter? • Different paths for packets • Network congestion • Not implementing packet prioritization • Poor hardware performance (old equipment) • Wireless jitter (interference in medium) 21CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Network Metrics: Throughput • Throughput: amount of data moved from one location to another in a given time • Usually expressed in bytes per second (B/s, MB/s, etc.) or bits per second (bps, Mbps, etc.) 22CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Network Metrics: GOODPUT • Goodput: rate at which useful data arrives • Does not include headers and encoding costs • Does not include data loss and retransmissions • May depend on context and application-layer protocol 23CPSC 317 – Computer Networking : Network Performance Maryam R.Aliabadi Goodput vs Throughput 24 Application Transport Network Data-link layer Physical Application
